Hey I'm Dejan, a maker, a techie and a mechatronics engineer. I'm making electronics and robotics projects for you to learn and make something cool on your own. Along this YouTube channel I also run the HowToMechatronics.com website. It's an educational website which provides additional value to this channel. Arduino Projects and Tutorials, DIY Projects, How It Works, Electronics, Robotics, CNC, 3D Printers, Tips & Tricks, Arduino Source Codes, Circuit Schematics, Download files and much more can be found at www.HowToMechatronics.com

Whiteknuckle157

il y a 1 an •
As this is your first attempt to construct an entire airframe on your own without any RC flight experience, I would call this a huge success! Great work. Two constructive details that I would alter in the next iteration: make the wings dihedral since then the plane becomes self stabilizing, and make the rear end much smaller i.e. less massive or, as modelbuilders say "add some lightness". A tail heavy plane is not flyable for a beginner. You might check out the flite test yt channel for more inspiration. This helped me a lot getting into RC plane building. - Concerning the arduino RC control: this is a masterpiece. Simple and beautiful. i like it.

Catalina Hunter

il y a 1 an •
Great video. It's pretty amazing what you have done. From my experience in RC, you need to build light or if not, build bigger. I have a wonderful Ikarus Shock Flyer Super Star that is made of thin Depron and has a wingspan of 800 mm, a length of 750 mm and a flying weight of about 200 g. So the servos are very small and the receiver is tiny. The plane flies really well. Sure, I've crashed it too and it is taped together like yours. Easier to hand launch and then land on its belly in grass. If I was to build a plane that had the size of receiver you have, I'd build it similar to the Multiplex Parkmaster with a wingspan of 975 mm and a higher wing loading. Try make it from Elapor if you can get it, or Depron. You can then end up with a flight weight of around 520 g. Use carbon rods to reinforce.

First of all,it's definitely a big success as your first DIY RC plane.Great jobs! Suggestions: add some 'EXPO' to your controller output(instead of linear mapping,controller is less senaitive near neutural position.) change rudder trim to elevator trim,that's used more often. use XPS foam instead, it's much stronger. search 'basic aircraft design rules' for easily determine Cg, stablizer size etc. check out Andrew Newton 's channel, he is an expert at building foam board plane.
